Key Match Events: Iceland's Jón Dagur Þorsteinsson scored the only goal of the game at Wembley in the 12th minute, finishing off a sharp break with a low shot through John Stones's legs to beat goalkeeper Aaron Ramsdale at his near post.

England spurned several opportunities to equalise, including Anthony Gordon slicing his shot well over the bar and Harry Kane missing a golden chance in the 28th minute when he shinned Cole Palmer's cross over from six yards out.
Pre-Game Insights: Former England defender Matthew Upson said on BBC Radio commentary that England had 'no width, no punch of directness or aggression or physicality in the play', and that it was'really quite dismal'.

England coach Gareth Southgate told Channel 4 that the result was 'good' for the team, saying they had to 'be better without the ball' and that they hadn't had their full side out across any two games.
Post-Match Reflections: Former England players Wayne Rooney and Joe Cole were more positive, saying England needed to look at the bigger picture and that the result was not the most important thing tonight, it's about players getting experience.
Gareth Southgate said that they had to 'be better without the ball' and that they had a lot of things to put right quickly.
Miscellaneous Highlights: England only managed a single shot on target against the European minnows.
Southgate will also have concerns over the fitness of centre back Stones, who was replaced at half-time after appearing to roll his ankle in the first minute.
Others: The defeat drew comparisons to England's stunning defeat to Iceland at the 2016 European Championships, a result that knocked England out of the tournament and cost Roy Hodgson his job.
